sen.j: 健磐龍命（たけいわたつのみこと）とは、日本神話に登場する人物で、阿蘇神社の主祭神である。
sen.e: TAKEIWATATSU no Mikoto is a person that appears in Japanese myths as the major enshrined deity at Aso-jinja Shrine.
TAKEIWATATSU no Mikoto is a person that appears in Japanese myths as the major enshrined deity at Aso-jinja Shrine.
TAKEIWATATSU no Mikoto is a person that appears in Japanese myths as the major enshrined deity at Aso-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 神武天皇の子である神八井命の子として皇統に組み込まれているが、元々は阿蘇で信仰されていた阿蘇山の神 (神道)とみられる。
sen.e: TAKEIWATATSU no Mikoto is part of the imperial line (as a child of Kamuyai no Mikoto who in turn was a child of Emperor Jimmu) however, is viewed as the deity (Shinto) of Mt Aso who was worshiped at Aso.

TAKEIWATATSU no Mikoto is part of the imperial line (as a child of Kamuyai no Mikoto who in turn was a child of Emperor Jimmu) however, is viewed as the deity (Shinto) of Mt Aso who was worshiped at Aso.

TAKEIWATATSU no Mikoto is part of the imperial line (as a child of Kamuyai no Mikoto who in turn was a child of Emperor Jimmu) however, is viewed as the deity (Shinto) of Mt. Aso who was worshiped at Aso.

sen.j: 祖父である神武天皇の命をうけ、阿蘇山へ来た健磐龍命は、外輪山の上から目の前に広がる湖を眺めた。
sen.e: TAKEIWATATSU no Mikoto who was ordered by his grandfather (Emperor Jimmu) to come to Mt. Aso looked out from the rim of the crater and viewed a lake spreading out below him.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: TAKEIWATATSU no Mikoto who was ordered by his grandfather (Emperor Jimmu) to come to Mt. Aso looked out from the rim of the crater and viewed a lake spreading out below him.
TAKEIWATATSU no Mikoto who was ordered by his grandfather (Emperor Jimmu) to come to Mt. Aso looked out from the rim of the crater and viewed a lake spreading out below him.

sen.j: 広大さに感心して、水をなくして田畑を造ろう、と考えた。
sen.e: Taken aback by the size and breadth of this lake he drained it of water and turned the land into fields it is thought.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Taken aback by the size and breadth of this lake he drained it of water and turned the land into fields it is thought.
Taken aback by the size and breadth of this lake he drained it of water and turned the land into fields it is thought.

sen.j: そこで、外輪山の一部を蹴破ろうとしたが、一度目に挑戦したところはなかなか蹴破れなかった。
sen.e: Then he set about trampling down part of the outer crater but, when he first tried he couldn't quite kick his way through.
Then he set about trampling down part of the outer crater but, when he first tried he couldn't quite kick his way through.
Then he set about trampling down part of the outer crater but, when he first tried he couldn't quite kick his way through.

sen.j: それは、山が二重になっていているからで、以後、その場所は「二重（ふたえ）の峠」と呼ばれるようになった。
sen.e: This was because the mountain consisted of 2 layers: subsequently this spot came to be called 'Two Layer Ridge'(Futae no Toge).
This was because the mountain consisted of 2 layers: subsequently this spot came to be called 'Two Layer Ridge'(Futae no Toge).
This was because the mountain consisted of 2 layers: subsequently this spot came to be called 'Two Layer Ridge' (Futae no Toge).

sen.j: 別の場所で挑戦したら、今度は見事に蹴破ることに成功したが、そのはずみで健磐龍はしりもちをついてしまい、「立てぬ」と叫ぶようになった。
sen.e: When he tried at a different location, he was able to successfully break all the way through the rim however, the inertia caused TAKEIWATATSU to fall on his buttocks which lead to the place being called `No can stand`(`Tatenu`立てぬ).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: When he tried at a different location, he was able to successfully break all the way through the rim however, the inertia caused TAKEIWATATSU to fall on his buttocks which lead to the place being called `No can stand`(`Tatenu`立てぬ).

When he tried at a different location, he was able to successfully break all the way through the rim however, the inertia caused TAKEIWATATSU to fall on his buttocks which lead to the place being called 'No can stand' (Tatenu '立てぬ').

sen.j: 以後、その場所は「立野」と呼ばれるようになった。
sen.e: Subsequently, the place came to be called `Tateno`(立野).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Subsequently, the place came to be called `Tateno`(立野).
Subsequently, the place came to be called 'Tateno' (立野).

sen.j: また、蹴破ったところからは、湖水が一気に西の方に流れ出て、数匹の鹿が流されてしまったことから、以後「数鹿流（すがる）が滝」と呼ばれるようになった。
sen.e: Also, water suddenly flowed out westwards from the place where he kicked through the rim of the mountain and, several head of deer were also swept away leading to the place to be subsequently called `Sugaru (lit. several deer flow) Waterfall.

Also, water suddenly flowed out westwards from the place where he kicked through the rim of the mountain and, several head of deer were also swept away leading to the place to be subsequently called `Sugaru (lit. several deer flow) Waterfall.

Also, water suddenly flowed out westwards from the place where he kicked through the rim of the mountain and, several head of deer were also swept away leading to the place to be subsequently called 'Sugaru (lit. several deer flow) Waterfall.'

sen.j: 湖水が引くと、底から巨大なナマズが現れ、湖水をせき止めていたので、健磐龍は刀でナマズを切り、ようやく湖水は流れていった。
sen.e: With the falling lake levels large catfish emerged from the depths which stopped the outflow from the lake and so, TAKEIWATATSU cut the fish with his sword allowing the water to flow from, the lake again.

With the falling lake levels large catfish emerged from the depths which stopped the outflow from the lake and so, TAKEIWATATSU cut the fish with his sword allowing the water to flow from, the lake again.

With the falling lake levels large catfish emerged from the depths which stopped the outflow from the lake and so, TAKEIWATATSU cut the fish with his sword allowing the water to flow from, the lake again.
